I would just tell the Ubuntu installer to use the available free space.
Do you have another OS which hasn't been deleted, like Windows, which you would like to be able to boot?
That can be fixed without installing Ubuntu (though installing Ubuntu will also fix it).
well, how else can i fix it considering I don't have the windows 7 CD?
You can restore a Microsoft style MBR using an Ubuntu LiveCD.
sudo software-properties-gtk -e universe && sudo apt-get update && sudo apt-get install mbr && sudo install-mbr /dev/sda
alright. So, I just do those in Terminal, and then restart?

Keeping in mind that the device, "/dev/sda" was only a guess (should be your first hard drive, but you should check) and that whatever device you choose it should *NOT* have a number after it, so "/dev/sdb" might be right but *NOT* "/dev/sdb1".
